pull_request.title: Remove EnumDecl visitation
pull_request.body:
It was introduced in #742 to report underlying type aliases but it is seemingly not needed anymore, probably after #775 where `TypedefType` visitation has been added.

No functional change.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -281,6 +281,23 @@ comment:
 The args are added to the `include-what-you-use` command as-written after line
 unwrapping, so IWYU flags must be explicitly prefixed with `-Xiwyu`.
 
+### Prerequisites ###
+
+If a test has prerequisites, annotate the `.cc` file itself using a
+directive comment:
+
+```
+// IWYU_REQUIRES: feature(value)
+// IWYU_UNSUPPORTED: feature(value)
+```
+
+`IWYU_REQUIRES` states that the following feature test must evaluate
+true for the test to be valid.
+
+`IWYU_UNSUPPORTED` states that the test is invalid when the feature
+test evaluates as false.

issue.title: no include suggested for `std::swap()`

comment.body:
The specialization for `std::swap(std::basic_string, std::basic_string)` is defined to come from `<string>`: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/swap2

Locally in my libc++ headers, I also see that `swap` definition in `c++/v1/string` (which is the right file).

I think the IWYU behaviour is correct here.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -419,6 +430,78 @@ def _GetLaunchArguments(cc_file):
   return shlex.split(args)
 
 
+class Features:
+  """ Implements feature support functions for prerequisites. """
+
+  # Parses the output of 'include-what-you-use -print-targets'.
+  SUPPORTED_TARGET_RE = re.compile(r'^\s+([a-z0-9_-]+)\s* - .*$')
+
+  def __init__(self):
+    # Maps all known features names to prerequisite predicates.
+    self.known = {
+      "target": Features.Target
comment.body:
Thinking about this overnight, `IWYU_UNSUPPORTED: supports-targets(arm64)` (or whatever we end up calling it) is not something anyone would ever use in a test.

If a test doesn't select a `-target` then the prerequisite would be saying that `arm64` support is somehow causing our test to fail even when it's not being used. Same if the test is running with a non-`arm64` target - support for the arm64 target would somehow be polluting the behavior of the target being used.

The final case to consider is when the test asks for `-target arm64`: the prerequisite would be saying the test is invalid if IWYU has support for target. That's clearly a contradiction.

Obviously it should be accepted syntax. If it reads wrong, I don't think that's not the worst thing - as it will make the reviewer think a bit more (hopefully). What must read well is the positive case `IWYU_REQUIRES: supports-target(arm64)`

comment.body:
My concern with just `target` is that it might be confused with the compiler target triple.

Also it's not the target that IWYU would compile by default, so I feel `supports-target` would be preferable. Maybe `supports-arch`? Not sure.

pull_request.title: Add infrastructure to allow skipping tests
pull_request.body:
There may be reasons to skip a test. This infrastructure allows each test to define a condition under which it would skip. This is done by adding an '// IWYU_SKIP:' comment. The following text is evaluated as python code - if the result is true, the test is skipped.

I was looking at whether I could silence the `ms_inline_asm`, but saw the discussion on #1201. I'm not sure whether you'd prefer to set --target=x86_64, or mark the test for skipping with something like this. The infrastructure may come in handy to skip over tests that we can't get to work with libstdc++ or clang_mapping.

repo.name: include-what-you-use

issue.title: Add infrastructure to allow skipping tests
issue.body:
There may be reasons to skip a test. This infrastructure allows each test to define a condition under which it would skip. This is done by adding an '// IWYU_SKIP:' comment. The following text is evaluated as python code - if the result is true, the test is skipped.

I was looking at whether I could silence the `ms_inline_asm`, but saw the discussion on #1201. I'm not sure whether you'd prefer to set --target=x86_64, or mark the test for skipping with something like this. The infrastructure may come in handy to skip over tests that we can't get to work with libstdc++ or clang_mapping.

comment.body:
No worries :) I wasn't planning on doing anything further on this, I just wanted to test your change and add some documentation - you've picked those up, so that's great.

I'll close down this PR, and let you drive #1315
